passage:
(1) The Earth orbits around the sun once every 365.25 days, but the Earth's axis of rotation is not perpendicular to its orbital plane. Instead, it is tilted at an angle of approximately 23.5 degrees from the vertical. This tilt remains pointed in the same direction throughout the year, which means that as the Earth travels around the sun, different parts of the planet receive varying amounts of sunlight at different times.

(2) When the Northern Hemisphere is tilted toward the sun, it receives more direct sunlight and experiences summer. During this same period, the Southern Hemisphere is tilted away from the sun, receiving less direct sunlight and experiencing winter. Six months later, the situation reverses, with the Southern Hemisphere enjoying summer while the Northern Hemisphere endures winter.

(3) The changing seasons affect not only temperature but also the length of daylight. During summer in either hemisphere, that region experiences more hours of daylight than darkness. This happens because a larger portion of that hemisphere remains in sunlight during the Earth's daily rotation. Conversely, winter days are shorter because less of that hemisphere is exposed to sunlight as the Earth rotates.

(4) Spring and autumn (fall) occur during the transitional periods when neither hemisphere is significantly tilted toward or away from the sun. During these seasons, both hemispheres receive roughly equal amounts of sunlight, resulting in moderate temperatures between the extremes of summer and winter. These are known as the equinoxes, when day and night are approximately equal in length across the globe.

(5) It is important to understand that the Earth's distance from the sun is not the primary factor causing the seasons. In fact, the Earth is actually closest to the sun in January, during winter in the Northern Hemisphere. This demonstrates that it is the angle at which sunlight strikes the Earth, determined by the planet's axial tilt, rather than proximity to the sun, that is responsible for the changing seasons we experience throughout the year.

questions.question: Which form correctly completes the sentence? 'She _____ to the store yesterday.'
Choose the correct form: 'If I _____ rich, I would buy a big house.'
Which sentence is grammatically correct?

options.C: He didn't went to school yesterday.

options.D: I will to help you tomorrow.

options.B: The cake was eaten by the children.
options.C: They building a new house now.
options.D: The car has drove by John.

options.B: She suggested to go to the movies.

According to the passage, what causes the Earth to experience different seasons?

options.A: The Earth's varying distance from the sun
options.B: The Earth's rotation on its axis
options.D: The sun's changing position in the sky

questions.question: When it is summer in the Northern Hemisphere, what season is it in the Southern Hemisphere?

options.A: Because the Earth moves faster in summer
options.B: Because a larger portion of that hemisphere is exposed to sunlight
options.C: Because the sun shines brighter in summer
options.D: Because the Earth is closer to the sun in summer

questions.question: What happens during the equinoxes?

options.A: The Earth is closest to the sun
options.C: Day and night are approximately equal in length
options.D: The sun appears directly overhead at the equator

questions.question: Which statement is TRUE according to the passage?

options.A: The Earth is closest to the sun during summer in the Northern Hemisphere
options.B: The Earth is closest to the sun in January
options.C: The Earth's distance from the sun is the main cause of seasons
options.D: The Earth's axis changes direction throughout the year
